title: My own claim or representative
h1: Claiming on your own or on behalf of someone else
p1: A representative is someone who can act on your behalf to complete the claim, write to the employment tribunal or present your case at a hearing.
legend: Are you making the claim for yourself, or representing someone else?
detailsSummary1: Who can act as a representative?

detailsText1.li4: trade unions (if one is available to you)
detailsText1.li6: advisers from law clinics or law centres
detailsText1.p2: Paid representation be through legal professionals, including:
detailsText1.li10: claims management companies (regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA))

detailsSummary2: How to find and get a representative?

detailsText2.p1: The following links open in a new tab
detailsText2.li1: Find a solicitor in England and Wales(opens in new tab) – list of solicitors run by The Law Society
detailsText2.li2: Find a solicitor in Scotland(opens in new tab) – database of solicitors run The Law Society of Scotland
detailsText2.li3: Free Representation Unit (FRU)(opens in new tab) – charity providing legal advice, case preparation and advocacy for people not eligible for legal aid or who cannot afford lawyers (this service is not available in Scotland)
detailsText2.li4: In Scotland, some university law clinics can provide advice and represenation. You can find a list at The Scottish University Law Clinic Network (SULCN)(opens in new tab)
detailsText2.li5: local ‘law centres’ – not-for-profit legal practices providing legal aid for people who cannot afford lawyers.
detailsText2.p2: A trade union may also be able to pay for a solicitor and free legal advice is available from Citizens Advice(opens in new tab) or Citizens Advice Scotland(opens in new tab).
detailsText2.p3: The Equality Advisory and Support Service(opens in new tab) can help with discrimination claims.
detailsText2.p4: Some people may also be able to get help to pay for legal advice through legal aid.
